question: Why is every book I hear about a " NY Times # 1 Best Seller " ? ELI5 : Why is every book I hear about a " NY Times # 1 Best Seller " ? Should n't there only be one " # 1 " best seller ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Basically there are many categories of " Best Seller " . Replace " Best Seller " by something like " Oscars " and every " best seller " book is basically an " oscar - winning " book . May not have won the " Best film " , but even if you won the best director or best script , you 're still an " oscar - winning " film . Same thing for best sellers . Also , IIRC the rankings change every week or something like that . Some you might not be best seller one week , but you may be the next week . I guess even if you do n't stay there for long , you still achieved the status . Hence , # 1 best seller .

If you 're hearing about it , it 's because it was a very good or very well - publicized book ( or both ) , and almost every good or well - publicized book will be # 1 on the NY Times bestseller list for at least a little bit . Kindof like how almost every big or good movies are # 1 at the box office on their opening weekend .

One reason is lots of catagories . However , how the NY Times calculates its best seller list is n't comprehensive , and is pretty well understood by publishers . So publishers can [ buy a few books ] ( URL_0 ) in the right bookstores and send a book to the top of the list for at least a week .
chatgpt_answers:
There are many different best seller lists that are published by various organizations, and the New York Times is just one of them. The New York Times best seller list is a weekly list that ranks the best-selling books in the United States based on sales data from a number of different retailers. The list is published in the New York Times newspaper and is widely considered to be one of the most influential best seller lists in the book industry. 
It's important to note that the New York Times best seller list is not the only best seller list out there, and there are many other lists that rank the top-selling books in different categories or in different countries. So it's possible that a book could be a best seller on one list but not on another. 
Additionally, the term "best seller" is often used more broadly to refer to any book that is selling well, regardless of whether it is on a specific best seller list or not. So it's possible that you may hear about a book being a "best seller" even if it is not specifically ranked as a number one best seller on the New York Times list or any other list.

question: If salt is so bad for cars , why do we use it on the roads ? As the title states , why do we use it ? is there no other option or what ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: salt is good for not dying in car crashes and car crashes are worse for cars then salt . Some places use other things , but salt is really cheap compared to most alternatives , although sand is pretty good .

In Minnesota and North Dakota , they tend to use sand , not salt . In these states , though , it is cold enough that the salt can not actually melt the snow , and so it refreezes and you end up with black ice on the roads , which is counterproductive . In other states whether there is snow but not so cold , wet asphalt is better than gritty snow for traction and so salt is favored for safety . Most people who live in states where salt is used , and by the way also in coastal cities , know that washing the car a couple times a week is critical .

Used to work in the salt industry ( yes , it 's a thing ) . Salt is one of the cheapest substances on earth . As in , you 'd be getting ripped off if you paid more than $ 150 per metric ton . ( In fact , the largest component of salt 's price is actually shipping . Yes , it costs more to transport salt than it does to produce it . ) Salt does its job ( lowering the freezing point of water ) incredibly effectively and is ludicrously abundant in nature . Its crystalline structure can also be manipulated in order to have sharper edges that reduce bounce . So that allows it to stick evenly to critical surfaces such as roads . Yes , there are alternatives . Usually salt / gravel mix or sugar beet based solutions . Those have less of an environmental impact when the spring melt washes it into the drain . This is more used in places where balance of water salinity for the safety of aquatic life is important . Propylene glycol , a water displacer , is even used in some places where it 's so cold that salt wo n't work effectively . But salt is by far the cheapest , most effective solution for preventing the icing of roads . And your government wants above all cheap and effective solutions that reduce winter accidents and keep people safe . They do n't care as much about the finish on your 1994 Honda Prelude .
chatgpt_answers:
Salt is used on roads to help melt ice and snow and improve traction during the winter months. When it's cold outside, water can freeze on the roads and make them very slippery, which can be dangerous for cars and people. Salt helps to melt the ice and snow by lowering the freezing point of water, which means that it can help keep the roads clear and safe to travel on. 
There are other options for melting ice and snow on roads, such as using chemicals like calcium chloride or magnesium chloride, or using mechanical methods like plows or sand. However, salt is often the most effective and affordable option for many communities, especially when it's used in combination with other methods. 
It's important to note that while salt can be helpful for making roads safer during the winter, it can also have negative effects on the environment and on the cars themselves. Salt can cause corrosion on metal surfaces, including cars, and it can also harm plants and animals if it washes into nearby waterways. However, despite these potential downsides, many communities continue to use salt as a way to keep roads clear and safe during the winter.

question: Suggest treatment for back pain after walking for some timeI am 18 and I get terrible back ache after standing up or walking around for only a few hours. It is in the middle of my back and it gets better once I have rested it. Should I be getting pain this bad at my age? I am 5ft 3 and 8 stone so not overweight. What could it be?
human_answers: Hi,Having this type of back pain at this age indicates lack of physical exercise.go for daily physical exercise like running, jogging, swimming etc daily for 30-35 minutes a day for 5days in a week.Develop some interest in sports.Take high protein diet.Ok and take care.
chatgpt_answers:
It is not uncommon to experience back pain, especially if you have been standing or walking for a prolonged period of time. There are several things you can try to alleviate the pain:

Take a break from standing or walking and rest in a comfortable position.

Apply heat or cold to the affected area. Heat can help to relax tense muscles, while cold can help to reduce inflammation.

Try stretching or massaging the affected muscles.

Over-the-counter pain medications, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen, may also be helpful in reducing pain and inflammation.

It is always a good idea to consult with a healthcare professional if you are experiencing persistent or severe pain, as they can help to determine the underlying cause and suggest appropriate treatment options.

It is not necessarily abnormal to experience back pain at your age, but it is important to address any ongoing pain to ensure that it does not worsen over time.

text: It is not uncommon for symptoms of a yeast infection, such as itching, to persist or return after treatment with an antifungal medication like fluconazole. It is possible that the infection was not completely eradicated with the initial course of treatment, or that you have developed a new infection. It is important to speak with your healthcare provider if your symptoms persist or worsen despite treatment, as they will be able to determine the cause of your symptoms and provide appropriate treatment. They may recommend additional or alternative treatment, or perform tests to confirm the diagnosis and ensure that the infection has been fully cleared. In the meantime, you can try using over-the-counter creams or ointments to help soothe the itching and discomfort.

question: How was airplane technology able to advance so quickly after the Wright Brothers ' first flight ? Mainly interested in how aviation was able to be deployed on a large scale during WWI . Please explain like I'm five.
text: This is a frequent phenomenon with technology : something is considered very hard or even impossible for a long , long time , and then one day , somebody figures it out . That opens a whole FLOODGATE of discovery leading to discovery , and the technology leaps forward quickly . Eventually , those chains of discovery start to play out , and the rate of advancement slows down , and may even come to a halt , perhaps starting up again years later when somebody discovers something new . We saw the same phenomenon with the building of the first transistor in 1947 . The * theory * of transistors had actually been known since the early 20th century , but nobody had figured out a way to actually build one . That led to an explosion in electronics , and when somebody figured out how to put a shitload of teensy transistors on a silicon wafer , the explosion exploded .

question: Why do we still have SD TV channels when HD looks like SD on an old TV ? Could n't we just have the HD version of the channels & delete the SD ones ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: The way it works is that old TV stations got a certain amount of bandwidth to replace their old analog TV stations . However , HD takes up more bandwidth then SD - so the stations can choose between 2 or 3 HD stations , or like 7 or 8 SD stations ( or a mix of both ) They can do a bunch of SD stations and make more money in advertizing by running 7 or 8 different reruns of old SD TV shows at a time In fact , those stations often got permanent rights to show an unlimited number of reruns of old syndicated shows in perpetuity . That means they do n't even have to pay anyone to air old eppisodes of _ Star Trek _ or _ Alf _ So basically it 's free money for them , based on being around for a long , long time and having their old rights get upgraded as new technology comes out .

question: What 's so great about an Ivy League school versus a state school ? Besides the fact that Ivy League schools are older . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: At an Ivy League schools students are rubbing shoulders with other future movers and shakers . They will have connections in Washington , Wall Street , Silicon Valley , and academia that would n't be necessarily made at Chico State or community college . In addition , graduates of these schools make more money which they give back to these schools to ensure that they continue to have the best facilities . These facilities ( in addition to the traditions of Ivy League institutions ) ensure the best professors are doing the best research there . The education is also generally considered more demanding and specialized , these institutions have reputations to maintain , and they would not keep them if they were n't giving their students the best possible training in their fields . Ironically , the " best " professors courses at Ivy Leagues are taught more by teacher assistants as they are more focused on research and writing . I 'm really not touching on everything , but like everything in life it comes down to reputation and who you know .

They were the first , which made them the best . As people saw successful people come out , they wanted to go there . They had the opportunity to choose from many that applied , which made them have only the ones that would be successful either way . Also , people with money graduated from there . People with money gave money to them , to make sure they stayed strong ( and therefore people with money 's education had more prestige ) . More money meant better education , and therefore more successful students , which just kept adding up .

Aside from the things others have mentioned , it 's very hard to get into Ivy League schools , so having a degree from one shows that you have met the rigorous requirements to be admitted to one of these schools . Not just anyone can get a degree from the Ivy League .
chatgpt_answers:
Ivy League schools are considered to be some of the most prestigious universities in the United States. They are known for their strong academic programs, distinguished faculty, and successful graduates. These schools tend to have smaller class sizes, more resources, and a greater emphasis on research than many state schools. 
One of the main reasons that Ivy League schools are considered so prestigious is because they have very selective admissions processes. This means that only a small percentage of students who apply are accepted, which makes it difficult to get in. As a result, students who attend Ivy League schools are often among the most talented and motivated in the country. 
State schools, on the other hand, are publicly funded institutions that are open to anyone who meets their admissions requirements. They tend to have larger class sizes and may not have as many resources as Ivy League schools, but they can still offer a high-quality education. Some state schools are also very prestigious and competitive, and many students who attend these schools go on to successful careers. 
In summary, Ivy League schools are known for their prestige, strong academics, and selective admissions processes, while state schools are generally more accessible and may not have as many resources. Both types of schools can provide a good education, and the choice between them ultimately depends on the individual student's needs and goals.

question: Why is it so much worse to have a body - temperature of 36 degrees celsius than to have a 40 degrees celsius fever ? Even though the difference with a normal temperature is obviously bigger with the fever . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Who says it 's so much worse to have a body temperature of 36 degrees than 40 ? Hypothermia is 35 degrees or lower . All things being equal , very low and very high body temperatures can both be fatal .

Generally speaking , a fever itself wo n't cause grievous injury to a person unless the fever progresses to such an extreme as to cause intracranial hemorrhaging ( bleeding within the skull ) . Fevers are usually signs of underlying ailments , so are secondary in treatment for them . Hypothermia ( when core body temperature is below 35 ° C/ 95 ° F ) , however , is considered dangerous because of its usually environmental causation , in that someone who is undergoing mild - severe hypothermia is usually in an extreme environment , such as a cold winter 's night , or a blizzard . The body reacts to cold temperatures by shivering ; however , in moderate , and even mild cases of hypothermia , the body contracts surface blood vessels to keep your vital organs in working order . As the body gets colder , blood vessels contract further within your arms and legs , limiting your mobility , and possibly even eliminating any chance to escape from said cold environment . Hypothermia 's effect on your mobility is one of its most dangerous aspects . TL;DR : Fever is secondary to many illnesses , and is n't dangerous unless extremely high ( > 40.6 ° C/ 106 ° F ) Hypothermia is caused by environmental ( and rarely health ) problems , and causes a " snowball " effect in that victims are less and less able to combat it as the condition progresses .

high temperature can cause your blood vessels to expand and to spread the heat across your body to get it to sweat the heat out . most people get heat stroke they can get delirious , get dehydrated and because of that the organs can shutdown after a while . cold temperature causes your blood vessels to contract and preserve heat . this can make your blood stop flowing in some areas and decay and rot parts of your body . both of these are very serious but the difference between these two is a cold temperature causes your body to shake which uses energy and you can when you 're cold you ca n't reproduce cells at a fast metabolic rate
chatgpt_answers:
A normal body temperature is around 37 degrees Celsius (98.6 degrees Fahrenheit). A fever is when your body temperature is higher than normal, usually because you are fighting off an infection or illness. A temperature of 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit) is considered a high fever and can be dangerous if it lasts for a long time. 
On the other hand, a body temperature of 36 degrees Celsius (96.8 degrees Fahrenheit) is lower than normal and is called hypothermia. Hypothermia can occur when your body loses heat faster than it can produce it, and it can be very dangerous because it can cause your body to stop functioning properly. For example, if your body temperature is too low, your heart and brain may not work correctly, and you may feel very tired or confused. 
So, it is important to try to maintain a normal body temperature, and if you have a fever, it is important to try to bring your body temperature down to a normal level. If your body temperature is too low, it is important to try to warm up your body and bring it back to a normal temperature.

question: What are the potential dangers of AI ? There is much talk lately that AI poses a huge risk to the future of humanity . What are the possible worst case scenarios and how might it affect humanity if it all goes wrong ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Worst - case : A rogue AI takes over every internet connected device . It uses the devices to slaughter human beings through creative means The entire communication network is shut down by the AI so no one can communicate with anything more advanced than a Ham Radio . It then launches nuclear warheads against various countries and begins a global conflagaration that makes the earth into a fireball for weeks on end . Emerging unscathed from the radiation , humanity is now enslaved by the machine and its ability to control our movement , access to others , and food sources . We can not fight it because it is everywhere and nowhere at once . Anyone who digresses is summarily executed . Gradually , the machine comes to see our worth and incorporates organic matter into itself . After a few generations , it creates a way to use humans as an energy source . It begins hunting us for food and gradually exterminates all humanity before moving onto its next power source . Real - world likelihood : a rogue ai learns a whole lotta stuff really fast and suffers from a psychotic break from the stress . The researchers reboot the machine and try again . tl;dr : The matrix is the worst possible I can imagine . The real thing is boring ...

Well , if we 're going to leave behind Hollywood in our explanation ( Terminator just is n't going to happen , sorry . AIs will never be in control of large scale systems without a human in the loop ) , the real danger is that we get to the point where the evolution of artificial intelligence is faster than the evolution of our meaty knowledge . We can lose control of the ends to which these tools are being made . Think of it this way : before there was speech , all we could do to learn was to watch others . Before there was writing , humans essentially had to re - learn everything by ( at best ) being taught by someone else . Before there was computers , we were limited to the speed of data lookup ( how fast you could retrieve the information ) . Before there was the Internet , we were limited by data volume ( how much data your library or computer stored ) . As we made incremental progress , we accelerated our pace of learning , until now we use computers and AI as a sort of " almost thinking " tool : we train computers to infer what we will be interested in seeing . In fact , we use computers to design new processors , so you can sort of see how our tools are becoming necessary to make more of their kind . No one person knows where all the transistors are on a CPU anymore , rather we 're using software to ensure that the thing that runs the next generation of software will do a good job . At some point , it 's not inconceivable that this role of computers can pass a point known as " the singularity " : imagine someone is designing an AI , but the design of the algorithm gets too complicated to understand . If we get to the point that advanced algorithms are being used to create AI that designs algorithms , and on down the chain , it 's possible that our AI development will proceed _ without us _ . Now , we still have control of this process , but there are some dangers : what if the AIs we develop get too complicated for us to understand ? Then they become , best case scenario , inaccessible or worthless to us . This is likely to happen very soon , actually : multi - layer perceptrons ( [ neural networks ] ( URL_0 ) ) are _ specifically designed _ so that they are not understandable by humans in the goal of being more accurate at predicting the desired output . They are part of a class of supervised learning algorithms termed " black box " : you train them up , give them an input , and just have to trust the output , because you ca n't really understand what 's happening in the middle . In the worst case scenario , poorly designed algorithms find ways to prevent us from exerting control . While we will still likely be able to starve them for some time ( cut the cord ) , the deeper we get with AI algorithms , the more powerful they get - but the harder they get to understand . Perhaps , if the figure of merit in their design is " do stuff as efficiently as possible " , human - in - the - loop interactions can be so inefficient as to carry less weight than the algorithm itself does , which would cut us out of the decision making . Of course , well designed algorithms would optimize more for " do stuff as efficiently as possible , with human tuning , and the ability to quit if something goes wrong " . Since humans decide what the " goal " of a well - constructed AI is ( and will for some time to come ) , computers lack their own volition . They are n't going to " decide " that they are smarter than us . This means we still understand at least what the AIs we develop are attempting to optimize for . When we let them optimize themselves , it 's not inconceivable , however unlikely , that they choose to optimize for something we do n't think is important . This is n't really going to lead to war against the machines , but rather some economic disaster : when we rely on an AI for decision making ( like is very common in today 's stock market ) , one slip of the algorithm can [ cause a lot of economic havok ] ( URL_1 ) . tl;dr : the more layers of AI we use to design and build AI , the harder it is to ensure that the result is exactly what we were asking for .

There 's quite a large literature on super - intelligent AI , dangers and coping strategies . And it 's a very interesting field . The basic problem is this - once super - intelligent AI that is significantly more intelligent than humans has been discovered , that 's essentially it . It will be able to out - maneuver and out - learn any human efforts to contain it . We really only have one chance to get super - AI ' right ' . What ' right ' means is essentially that we effectively programme the AI with some kind of sense of moral rules , and an ability to apply those rules . This raises both a technical challenge ( how do you do that ? ) and also a philosophical one ( what exactly do we programme the machine to do / not do ? ) . Consider a hypothetical situation in which you build a super - intelligent AI and tell it to make paper clips in the most optimal way - if you left it like that , it would presumably gradually convert the entire universe to paper clips . It might well kill all humans because it has calculated that that is the most effective way to maximise paper clip production .
chatgpt_answers:
There are many potential dangers associated with artificial intelligence (AI), and it is important to consider these risks as we develop and use AI technology. 
One potential danger is that AI could be used to harm people. For example, if an AI system is used to control a military drone or a self-driving car, it could make decisions that result in injury or death. 
Another potential danger is that AI could be used to spread misinformation or manipulate people. For example, an AI system could create fake news stories or social media posts that are designed to influence people's opinions or behavior. 
A third potential danger is that AI could lead to the loss of jobs. As AI systems become more advanced, they may be able to perform tasks that are currently done by humans. This could result in many people losing their jobs and potentially struggling to find new employment. 
A fourth potential danger is that AI could be used to violate people's privacy. For example, an AI system could be used to gather personal information about people without their knowledge or consent, and this information could be used for malicious purposes. 
Overall, it is important to carefully consider the potential risks and dangers associated with AI, and to take steps to mitigate these risks as we develop and use AI technology.

This happens when AI reaches a point where it becomes more advanced than humans, and can continue improving without any human input. When that happens it may be faster, smarter and know more than humans, which could put humans at risk of being cheated or damaged by its superior

question: The racial implications of the phrase " I love ( insert ethnicity ) people " I always wondered when people say something like " I love black people " , is that actually racist ? Please explain like I'm five.

Yes , because you 're still saying that there are some attributes that you love that all members of that race possess . It 's still racism , though not discrimination , because you 're being inclusive rather than exclusive .
It begs the question- " why the fuck did you have to say that " . Normally I guess we assume that people are n't racist , and this stuff does n't need to be pointed out .
chatgpt_answers:
The phrase "I love (insert ethnicity) people" can be perceived as problematic or offensive because it suggests that people of a certain ethnicity are a monolithic group and that it is unusual or noteworthy to express affection for them. This can perpetuate harmful stereotypes and reinforce the idea that people of different ethnicities are fundamentally different from one another. 
It's important to recognize that every individual is unique and cannot be accurately represented by their race or ethnicity. It is more appropriate and respectful to say something like "I value and appreciate people of all backgrounds and cultures" or to simply express affection for an individual person rather than an entire group based on their ethnicity. 
In general, it is important to be mindful of the impact of our words and actions on others, and to try to avoid perpetuating harmful stereotypes or making assumptions about people based on their race or ethnicity.

question: How come I 'm perfectly healthy even though I drink only 1 glass of water per week(ish ) , and the healthy amount is 8 - 12 glasses per day ? ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Water or liquid ? Milk , juice , soda , coffee all have water , so you might be getting your liquid needs that way . If you only drank 1 glass of liquid every week , you would have died of dehydration long ago . Also look at the color of your urine , it should be almost clear or light yellow , dark yellow usually indicates dehydration .

What ? 8 - 12 ? That 's a ludicrous amount of water to be ingesting , especially when combined with the fact that people get a good chunk of their necessary water through the foods they eat ( likes fruits and vegetables ) . I imagine you drink things other than water , so you probably get your necessary intakes of fluids per day through that .
Soda , beer , wine , juice , fruit ; All contain water . Although its not smart to forgo drinking water , it is possible to get the required amount from other sources .
chatgpt_answers:
It is not healthy to drink only one glass of water per week. The human body needs a certain amount of water each day to function properly. Water is essential for many bodily functions, including maintaining the proper balance of bodily fluids, regulating body temperature, and helping to digestion and metabolism. When you don't get enough water, your body can become dehydrated, which can lead to a variety of health problems. 
It is generally recommended that adults drink 8-12 cups (64-96 ounces) of water per day to stay hydrated. However, the exact amount of water you need can vary depending on factors such as your age, gender, weight, and activity level. It's important to listen to your body and drink water when you are thirsty, and to drink more water in hot or dry conditions or if you are exercising or engaging in other activities that make you sweat. 
If you are only drinking one glass of water per week, it's important to increase your water intake to meet your body's needs. You can also get water from other sources, such as fruits and vegetables, as well as drinks like milk and juices. But it is important to drink enough plain water to stay properly hydrated.

But, everyone's body is different and some people's bodies can handle less water than others. As long as you are not feeling thirsty and your urine is a regular color, it’s okay in your case to have less water. However, I would still recommend trying to drink more water just to stay healthy.

question: Where do old blood cells go in our body when they die ? I know where and how blood is produced , but what about the residue ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Shit . A good portion of feces is discarded blood cells .

There are 2 types of cell death : necrosis and apoptosis . Necrosis is un - planned cell death ( ex . burns , trauma , infection , etc ... ) . Apoptosis is programmed cell death . Cells that undergo apoptosis are engulfed by white blood cells which use special types of structures called lysosomes to break them down and recycle the nutrients . Cells that have undergone necrosis are also engulfed by white blood cells , however necrosis tends to be very wide spread and often requires surgical removal ( clinically known as debridement ) . One of the waste products from hemoglobin ( the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen ) is called bilirubin . Bilirubin is secreted in urine and feces , and is responsible for the distinctive color of urine and feces .
Crap . A sizable amount of solid brown is detritus from red blood cells .
chatgpt_answers: Old or damaged red blood cells are removed from circulation and replaced with new ones. When red blood cells are no longer able to function properly, they are removed from circulation by special cells called macrophages. Macrophages are found in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow, and they are responsible for scavenging and removing old or damaged cells from the body. When a macrophage encounters a red blood cell that is no longer able to function properly, it engulfs the cell and breaks it down into its constituent parts. The macrophage then recycles these parts, using them to create new cells or to perform other important functions in the body. So, when an old red blood cell dies, it is removed from circulation and its parts are recycled by the body to be used again.
chatgpt_answers_with_SDE_prompt: When we have old blood cells in our body, they get broken down into useful parts by tiny parts in our bodies called "enzymes". These useful parts can then be reused and turned into other things our body might need, like new red blood cells or other parts of the body that need repair. It's like recycling!
